hero_dishes.name: Royal Imperial Cuisine (Tasting Menu)
hero_dishes.description: An elaborate 8-9 course tasting menu recreating the royal dining experience with artistically presented miniature dishes. Each dish celebrates Hue's imperial heritage with meticulous preparation and presentation. Includes around 50 small dishes in the full experience.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Emperor Tu Duc demanded a unique meal every night, forcing royal chefs to innovate constantly. This created Vietnam's most refined culinary tradition - dishes originally developed for Vietnamese royalty, now served in restaurants where diners dress as kings, queens, and princes for $15-20 USD.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tinh Gia Vien Restaurant (2-decade legacy, chef with royal lineage), Ancient Hue Restaurant (traditional wooden house, artistic presentation), royal-themed restaurants near the Imperial City

hero_dishes.description: Delicate steamed rice cakes in small ceramic dishes, topped with dried shrimp, crispy pork skin, scallion oil, and fish sauce. A survivor from the Nguyen Emperor period.

It was so beloved it became immortalized as a signature Hue dish, representing the refinement of imperial cuisine in accessible street food form.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Hue's Old Quarter, Lac Thien (popular restaurant near Imperial City)

hero_dishes.origin_story: A Hue variation of Vietnamese pancakes, distinguished by its smaller size and extra crispiness - reflecting the imperial preference for refined, delicate presentations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lac Thien (one of the most popular restaurants in Hue, near Imperial City)

signature_drinks.name: Lotus Tea (Tr√† Sen)
signature_drinks.description: Delicate green tea scented with lotus flowers from Hue's lakes. The lotus was grown by the Royal family and remains Hue's signature ingredient.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in traditional teahouses, often after meals. Hue's lotus is considered the best in Vietnam, a direct legacy of the royal gardens.

signature_drinks.name: Hue Che (Sweet Dessert Soup)
signature_drinks.description: Refined sweet soups influenced by Imperial Cuisine, often made with lotus seeds from royal lotus ponds. Varieties include multiple layers of beans, jellies, and coconut milk.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed as a dessert or afternoon treat. The lotus seed version is uniquely Hue, reflecting the royal family's cultivation traditions.

food_culture_notes: Hue was once home to the Nguyen Dynasty royal families, making 'a meal fit for a king' literally true here
The term 'imperial cuisine' or 'royal cuisine' refers to 8-9 course set menus recreating royal dining experiences
Many popular Hue dishes originated in royal kitchens but are now accessible street food
Located only 5 miles from the coast, Hue combines imperial refinement with fresh coastal ingredients
Royal restaurants offer costumed dining experiences where tourists dress as royalty for $15-20 USD
The Perfume River (H∆∞∆°ng River) provides the romantic backdrop for many dining experiences
